docs.title: Home
docs.text:
Hello! doc.jp is a central place for my Japanese learning resources, goals, plans, etc.

Important

This documenation is intended for my use and not for a broader use case. However, if you find something useful, please use it!

docs.title: Grammar
docs.text: I keep track of the grammar points I need to work on (from my studies every day). I house those on a separate page which can be found here.

docs.title: Goals
docs.text: I set goals for my learning every month! I house my goals in a separate page which can be found here.

docs.title: Tool Setup
docs.text: I like to keep track of the various guides I use for setting up tools for sentence mining and yomichan. I house these in a separate page which can be found here.

docs.title: Resources
docs.text: I tend to use a lot of different resources and I like to keep track of them all. They can be found in a separate page here.

docs.title: Study Plan
docs.text: I like to formulate a general plan for myself in terms of studying. I will sometimes veer off this, but try and update it when I can. Regardless, this can be found here.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This is where I'll house my long term goals for learning Japanese.

docs.title: Goals
docs.text:
• Take and Pass the JLPT N3
  • Play Persona 5 Royal in Japanese with Japanese Subtitles by my 29th birthday
  • Watch Parasyte: The Maxim in japanese with Japanese subtitles by my 29th birthday

docs.title: December 2023 Goals
docs.text: • Finish N5 Grammar on Bunpro

docs.title: November 2023 Goals
docs.text:
Success

All complete

  • Review grammar on bunpro everyday
  • Do at least 5 cram study sessions on currently known grammar on bunpro
  • Study 10 new vocab every day

docs.title: Stretch Goal
docs.text: • Finish Japanese From Zero book 3 (might not get to until December as I want to focus mostly on grammar review this month)

docs.title: October 2023 Goals
docs.text:
Success

All complete

  • Finish Japanese From Zero book 2~~: Finished
  • Learn 300 vocabulary words 10 per day (will bring me to 569 vocabulary words learned)
  • Immerse with two episodes of Laid Back Camp (Yuru Camp)

ALL COMPLETE

docs.title: Goals
docs.text:
• Finish Tango N4 Vocabulary Anki Deck

  • Finish Genki 1 and Genki 2

  • Read and understand 10 NHK easy news articles

  • Read and understand 10 Satori Reader stories

docs.title: Stretch Goals
docs.text: None at the moment

docs.title: January 2024 Goals
docs.text: • Finish Genki 1 and all workbook work

docs.title: Grammar
docs.text:
So, I want to take some time to just restart bunpro. There are a couple of reasons for this:

  • I somewhat rushed through some of it and didn't really give myself time to fully understand some of the grammar points.

  • I also rushed through some of it

Both of these reasons have caused me to forget a lot of the grammar points I've learned or am learning.

I will list all the grammar points I've currently learned on bunpro in the previously sutdied section of this document. As I re-study or re-practice the grammar points I've previously done on bunpro, I will remove them from the previously studied section to keep track of what I have left. These items will then go to the grammar points learned section.

I'm also still going through the genki series, so I will add those to the grammar points learned section as well.

This is obviously a horrible system. But it'll work.

docs.title: When did I start learning Japanese?
docs.text: I started learning Japanese seriously on 08/21/2023.

docs.title: Why did I start learning Japanese?
docs.text:
As cliche as this is going to sound, I think the biggest reason I want to learn Japanese is because I want to live a life without regrets.

I've always been enamoured by the Japanese language. Japan is a beautiful country with a beautiful language. I think I really got into Japanese after playing persona 5 for the first time when it came out. The aesthetic of Japan was alluring and I started to get really into Japanese music and food. From there I started to watch anime, and my love for Japan grew even further. Obviously, that translated into me wanting to learn Japanese, although I was never super invested in learning the language.

I turn 30 in four years (less now). I can't believe I'm more than half way through my 20s. I've done so much with my life: I've travelled all over the united states in a van, obtained a bachelors degree, got engaged. But there's something that's always nagged me in the back of my subconscious. When I search deep within myself, Japanese always peers back at me.

I don't want to turn 30 without learning Japanese in some capacity. That's not gonna happen. I guess this is why I'm learning Japanese: It's something I've wanted to do for a long time and there's no possible way I'm not gonna learn it.

docs.title: Study Plan
docs.text: I wanted a place to formulate some thoughts on my intended path going forward for studying. This is likely to change as I get further in my learning journey, but this is will always be what my current study plan is at the moment.

docs.title: Plan as of 12/31/2023
docs.text: Right now, I'm going through the Tango N4 vocab deck and am reviewing Tango N5. I tried doing some sentence mining instead of Tango N4, but I think it would be better if I just stuck to this deck and really worked on my grammar heavily. I've come up with a new plan:

docs.title: What's remaining the same
docs.text:
• I'm on track to complete Tango N4 in march assuming nothing crazy happens. I will continue working through that deck and reviewing Tango N5.

  • Will continue to reinforce my grammar knowledge using bunpro as an srs mechanism.

docs.title: What is the new stuff
docs.text:
I feel like I'm become somewhat stagnant with my grammar intake. I would like to change this moving into the new year

  • I plan on revisiting Genki 1 for grammar and really taking my time and working through the grammar and doing the practice in the workbook and at the end of the section (as well as at the end of the book)

    • I will move on to Genki 2 after Genki 1 when I feel very confident on everything in the book.

    • Will likely use TokiniAndy videos/course if I feel I need it.

  • Will begin satori reader stories/nhk easy news when I finish Tango N4.

docs.title: Currently Using
docs.text:
Important

I add and remove items from here all the time. I'm finding new resources all the time so I will update this page monthly so it's not always correct.

docs.title: Grammar
docs.text:
• Genki 1: Grammar textbook

  • Bunpro: Pretty cool. Groups grammar points by N~ level or by textbook. Will essentially make the equivolent of an Anki deck in the UI. I use it more so for repetition but I learn from text books.

docs.title: Dictionaries
docs.text:
• Jotoba: A really helpful dictionary I prefer over Jisho

  • Jisho: Tried and true lookup dictionary

  • Tokoboto: Another dictionary I like to use from time to time. Not as much as the other two however

docs.title: Browser Extensions
docs.text: • Yomichan: Yomichan is a browser extension that allows you to look up Japanese words with both the meaning and the reading on web pages with ease.

docs.title: Not Using Currently
docs.text:
Important

I add and remove items from here all the time. I'm finding new resources all the time so I will update this page monthly so it's not always correct.

Info

These resources are the online resources I've found or are using. This will not include any type of textbook or anki deck.

I'm also not including youtube playlists or channels as I have those stored in youtube already (accessible anywhere)

docs.title: Grammar
docs.text:
• TokiniAndy Course: He has free youtube videos but the course is amazing. Has graded readers, shadowing practice, vocabulary review, textbook lesson and practice (Genki), and more. I'm not using it anymore as I'm following a different book than genki now.

  • Genki Study Resources By Seth Clydesdale: Amazing resource if you're going through Genki 1. Has a ton of practice for all lessons of Genki 1

docs.title: Graded Readers
docs.text:
• Tadoku Graded Readers: Free graded books

  • Satori Reader: Graded reader (paid)

  • NHK Easy News: Essentially a graded reader but with Japanese news

docs.title: Browser Extensions
docs.text:
• Asbplayer: Load local subtitle files to video streaming sites.

  • Migaku: Honestly, it's mostly just a sentence mining thing for me (used it a bit). But they have some other cool features and an in house SRS tool which is nice and works well with the extension (easier to use than Anki with less setup)

docs.title: Dictionaries
docs.text: • jpdb: Have pretty cool features. Also cool for generated Anki decks for anime, novels, etc. Essentially allowing you to skip sentence mining.

docs.title: TV / Movies
docs.text:
• Kitsunekko: Probably the biggest collection of Japanese subtitles for anime. An absolute lifesaver for immersion.

  • Super Native: Cool site that trains you to hear, read, and speak Japanese from TV and movies.

  • Language Reactor: Kind of like migaku or asbplayer in a way. Embeds directly to youtube or netflix (there are others). Allows you to mine from TV and movies.

  • Aniwatch.to: Anime streaming site (mostly use for anime that isn't on any streaming platforms like Crunchyroll, Hidive, Amazon, etc.)

  • Aniwave.to: Anime streaming site (mostly use for anime that isn't on any streaming platforms like Crunchyroll, Hidive, Amazon, etc.)

  • Animelon: Can actually stream anime with Japanese subtitles which is pretty cool. Don't use it a ton but.

docs.title: Manga
docs.text: • Mokuro: Allows you to read Japanese manga with Yomichan selectable text inside a browser.

docs.title: Games
docs.text: • Game2Text: Essentially adds the ability to parse Japanese from games

docs.title: Kanji
docs.text: • Kanji Map: Really cool resource for learning stroke patterns

docs.title: Podcasts
docs.text: • Japanese Podcast Spreadsheet: Has a huge list of podcasts in Japanese. There's also a list (starter pack), that's sorted by Japanese level.

docs.title: Sentence Search
docs.text:
• Immersion Kit: Made by game gengo (amazing youtuber!). You can search sentences from anime, games, etc. with translation.

  • Youglish: Sentences sourced from YouTube video subtitles. Great tool for pronunciation as the words are said by native speakers speaking naturally.

docs.title: Tool Setup
docs.text: Here is where I will have all the setup instructions/guides for the tools I use frequently. That way I can always keep track If I build a new computer/format my hard drives or if I need it on a secondary computer

docs.title: Current Guides
docs.text:
Here are the current pages although they aren't up to date. Will update them once I actually begin mining

  • Mining: Sentence Mining
  • Yomichan: Yomichan

docs.title: Sentence Mining Setup
docs.text:
For right now, I'm using a prebuilt anki templating system.

Info

I plan on making my own template with a variation of a couple of different templates in the future. As I'm not really mining a whole lot right now as I'm still building foundational vocabulary knowledge, creating my own template isn't necessary at the moment.

docs.title: Guide
docs.text: • JP Mining Note

docs.title: Yomichan Setup
docs.text: When searching for ways to start mining sentences from anime, yomichan was the resource the I used the most.

docs.title: Guides
docs.text:
I followed two guides (one for yomichan itself as I think it's a bit clearer, and one for setting up yomichan for mining)

  • JP Mining Note: For mining
  • TheMoeWay: For general Yomichan setup (dictionaries, etc.)
